sub_title: Researcher & Lecturer, University College Maastricht (UCM), Maastricht University
summary: I am a researcher and lecturer with a broad training in the social sciences (sociology, anthropology, methodology, politics, and European studies). I'm passionate about research methodology and asking questions that matter. Over the years, I have accumulated experience in research design, analysis, advice, lecturing, working across disciplinary and national boundaries, and in the organization of various universities and institutions. I like to bring people together to collaborate on projects (workshops, edited books, journals, research design, data collection). My expertise is in research methodology, inequality, gentrification, European studies, politics, and identity. I have particular research experience in Poland (2007-2008), Estonia (2009-2013), Italy (2009-2014), and the Netherlands (2010-present).

education.field_of_study: Urban Photography Summer School (Visual Sociology / Photography)
Essex Summer School  in Social Science Data Analysis
Social Cultural Sciences: Comparative  Research on Societies

projects.title: Imagining Europe - Dutch section
projects.description: Imagining Europe is a 4 year research project on different imaginations (conceptualizations) of 'Europe' not only across national boundaries (in Estonia, the Netherlands, and Italy), but also across different social groups within those societies. Examples of such specific groups are working class vs. political/cultural 'elites', ethnic/national minorities vs. majorities, and more. 'Europe' means something different according to all of those characteristics, and the central objects of study in this project are those patterns, their relation to national and European identities, and to people's political behaviour. The empirical approach is 'mixed' (both quantitative and qualitative), and is followed up by a 'social networks' component. The project has its roots in sociology, anthropology, and political sciences, but 'borrows' from a number of additional academic fields as well. The project is initiated and run by Jeroen Moes, who works at the European University Institute (EUI) in the department of Political and Social Sciences (SPS).

contributors.headline: Researcher & Lecturer, University College Maastricht (UCM), Maastricht University

projects.title: Learning from First-Generation Academics: Social Inequality and Cultural Capital at Maastricht University
projects.description: The purpose of this study is to examine the experiences of First-Generation Academics at Maastricht University (UM). With a grant from the Diversity and Inclusivity Initiative at UM, this research has received funding to find policy recommendations to support the study experience of First-Generation Academics (FGAs). Research in this field has not yet been conducted within the UM community and prior empirical studies do not account for application procedures or the course of study specific to UM. Conducting semi-structured individual interviews as well as focus groups to obtain insights into individual study experiences. These qualitative findings indicate that FGAs are lacking guidance throughout their studies yet are resilient and adaptable in accommodating for changing environments in the familial as well as the academic sphere. A quantitative survey distributed among UM faculties yields significant results in the perception of what it means to be a FGA. It also highlights further hurdles in the academic career of FGAs. Lastly, the research suggests preliminary policy recommendations to be implemented at a university-wide level to improve FGAs study experience at UM.

projects.title: Workshop on 'European Identity in Times of Crisis'
projects.description: The workshop had a sociological focus (but was open to other disciplines), and was organized over the course of 1.5 day. Attendees were invited speakers, professors and (PhD) researchers from the EUI and the University of Florence, and several 'external' academics. During and after the workshop, an active effort was made to compile a proposal for an edited book based broadly on the workshop topic. Some of the papers submitted for the workshop will be included as chapters (in edited form).

contributors.headline: Researcher & Lecturer, University College Maastricht (UCM), Maastricht University

projects.title: Social Network Analysis: Methodology and Research Design (Advanced SNA)
projects.description: The workshop spanned a total of four full, intensive days. The general aim of this workshop was to go beyond the basics of SNA, partly by building upon the theoretical and conceptual foundation laid out in the previous year’s workshop on SNA. However, at the same time we tried to keep the workshop fully accessible to researchers who are relatively unfamiliar with SNA.

contributors.headline: Researcher & Lecturer, University College Maastricht (UCM), Maastricht University
Data Scientist

projects.title: Methodological Workshop on Online Research Methods
projects.description:
The workshop had 4 blocks consisting of half a day each:

1.	Generic block introducing online methods
2.	Network analysis
3.	Virtual ethnography
4.	Online surveys and interviews

In addition, a practical exercise was carried out to enhance discussion and stimulate the participants to explore the potential of online methods, e.g. starting from a research questions related with online environment, we worked in groups in order to create a draft and short research design to find an answer, taking into account the presented methods.

projects.title: Methodological Workshop on Social Network Analyis (SNA)
projects.description: The workshop had an interdisciplinary and introductory approach to the analysis of social networks (SNA). The general focus was not on specific techniques for analysing networks, as is done in a number of other workshops across Europe (there are regularly such workshops during the summer in either Essex or LjubljanaI). Instead, we discussed the basic ontology and epistemology of the approach and possible applications in concrete research designs.

profile_positions.description:
Design and teaching of the research methods curriculum at University College Maastricht (UCM), which is the honours Liberal Arts College of Maastricht University. Lecturer for several courses and workshops, managing >9 Junior Teaching Fellows across various courses and projects.

> All my teaching revolves around research methodologies, empirical techniques and research design.
> This includes qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods designs, statistics, SPSS, ethnography, qualitative interviewing, survey design, social network analysis, visual methods, applied research, and thesis writing.

I'm chair of the FSE Faculty Council, a member of the Central Bureau of Examinations, member of the Board of Admissions, and founder / coordinator of the Methods Lab (www.methodslab.nl). My multidisciplinary and multi-method research interests focus on issues around gentrification, urban sociology, the radical right, educational inequality, and European integration.
profile_positions.title: Researcher / Lecturer

profile_positions.description: The Methods Lab gives advice to students and staff on research design and methodology and organizes workshops on many research-related topics. www.methodslab.nl
profile_positions.title: Founder & coordinator Methods Lab
Central Board of Appeal for Examinations

profile_positions.description: Comparative research on conceptualizations of 'Europe', in a mixed methods research design. 'Step 1' is a qualitative comparison of all European countries for which comparative data is available, followed by a more in-depth quantitative analysis of three specific cases (Italy, Estonia, Netherlands). 'Step 2' is an in-depth qualitative analysis of these three country cases, and 'Step 3' is a network analysis of transnational social networks of social/cultural elites. For more information, see www.imagining.eu
profile_positions.title: PhD Researcher (Political and Social Sciences)

profile_positions.description: Elected ‘Researcher Representative’ to represent the researchers within the EUI administration. Involved in organisation of curriculum, departmental meetings, researcher welfare, and logistics.
